item.title: Afghanistan: US takes control of Kabul airport to evacuate staff from country
item.description: Hundreds of locals rush to flee from the Taliban as US forces secure the airport to evacuate staff.

item.title: UK confident it can get Britons out of Afghanistan, Ben Wallace says
item.description: There are plans to evacuate hundreds more eligible individuals in the coming days, the defence secretary says.

item.title: Don't abandon Afghans who helped UK, Labour warns government
item.description: The party calls for safe asylum routes for interpreters and others who worked with British forces.

item.title: Minute's silence for Plymouth shooting victims
item.description: Five people were killed in the shooting on Thursday before Jake Davison took his own life.

item.title: Covid: Self-isolation ends for double-jabbed and under-18s
item.description: Rules change in England and Northern Ireland for contacts of people who test positive for Covid.

item.title: Plymouth shootings: Police asked to review gun licence process
item.description: Police in England and Wales are to assess the legitimacy of existing gun licences.

item.title: Haiti earthquake: Rescuers search for survivors as death toll climbs to 1,297
item.description: More than 1,200 people are known to have died after a powerful earthquake hit the nation on Saturday.

item.title: UK defence giant Ultra agrees to Â£2.6bn Cobham takeover
item.description: The deal to buy the major supplier to the Royal Navy is being monitored by the UK government.

item.title: Pingdemic: 'We got close to complete shutdown'
item.description: Businesses say self-isolation rule changes will have a "massive impact" on reducing staff shortages.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Spectators will not be allowed at the Games
item.description: Spectators will not be allowed at Paralympic Games events in Tokyo, organisers confirm.

item.title: India's dancing cop becomes internet star
item.description: An Indian police officer has become a social media sensation because of his viral dance videos.

item.title: Chaos at Kabul airport as thousands of Afghans try to flee Taliban
item.description: Video shows crowds of Afghans attempting to flee, as the Taliban take over the capital.

item.title: Will Taliban take country back to past, asks John Simpson
item.description: What sort of nation will Afghanistan be after 2021, asks the BBC's world affairs editor John Simpson.

item.title: Afghanistan conflict: As Kabul falls, Biden backlash grows
item.description: Soldiers, statesmen and Afghan-Americans criticise the president - but how will the public react?

item.title: Afghanistan conflict: The Air India flight out on a fateful Sunday
item.description: Air India's only flight to Kabul on Sunday circled for 90 minutes over the Afghan capital before landing.

item.title: Afghanistan: People flee Kabul as Taliban overrun cities
item.description: Roads out of the Afghan capital have been choked with traffic as people try to escape a Taliban takeover.

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban spokesman Suhail Shaheen calls the BBC - interview in full
item.description: A spokesman for the Taliban, Suhail Shaheen, called the BBC's Yalda Hakim, live on air.

item.title: Mapping the advance of the Taliban in Afghanistan
item.description: Maps of Afghanistan show who controls districts in fighting between the government and Taliban forces.

item.title: Afghan war: Kabul's young women plead for help as Taliban advance
item.description: They feel abandoned by the democratic world they thought they were part of, writes Yalda Hakim.

item.title: Afghanistan: Why is there a war?
item.description: As foreign forces pull out after 20 years of war, what did it achieve and what happens next?

item.title: Afghanistan: The people fleeing the north for safety in Kabul
item.description: The Taliban has taken new territories in the north, forcing thousands out of their homes.

item.title: Afghans living under Taliban lament loss of freedoms
item.description: Afghans in Taliban-controlled provinces describe life under its fundamentalist Islamist rule.

item.title: âNot an Afghanistan problem but a humanity problemâ - Gen McMaster
item.description: This is a frontier between barbarism and civilisation, a former US national security adviser says.

item.title: How do couples handle awkward chats about money?
item.description: From squabbles and lies to what they'd do if they won the lottery, we pose the awkward questions.

item.title: The papers: 'The West flees' as 'Taliban rule returns'
item.description: The Taliban seizing Afghanistan's capital, as the country's government collapses, dominates the front pages.

item.title: The zero-power sewage plant inspired by cows
item.description: Fifty sustainable sewage treatment plants have been built that work in similar way to a cow's stomach.

item.title: John O'Groats to Land's End paramotor flight for dementia research
item.description: Daniel Jones says he wants to get younger people talking about dementia.

item.title: Why is Israel demolishing homes in East Jerusalem?
item.description: Israel says the homes were built without planning permission and it is to try to keep East Jerusalem in order.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: Team GB given star-studded homecoming
item.description: Athletes attended a concert at London's SSE Arena, Wembley, to mark their return from Tokyo.

item.title: How do we slow down fast fashion?
item.description: The clothes we wear can have a huge impact on the climate, even more so than the aviation industry.

item.title: Cornwall rescue: Cat's meows alert rescuers to stricken owner
item.description: Piran the cat leads rescuers to its 83-year-old owner, who had fallen down a 70ft (21m) ravine.

item.title: A refugee puppet and meteor shower - stories you may have missed
item.description: We also travel back to the Ice Age and to Sao Paulo's tallest building in this week's round-up.

item.title: 'It's not just boys who can do it'
item.description: Girls take part in a summer scheme introducing them to careers traditionally viewed as jobs for men.

item.title: Social media fraud: The influencers promoting criminal scams
item.description: BBC Panorama investigates a new generation of fraudster that openly uses social media to promote crime.

item.title: There and back again: The epic adventures of China's wandering elephants
item.description: After a mammoth journey across the country the pack of pachyderms are finally heading home.

item.title: Would you let a robot lawyer defend you?
item.description: Why artificial intelligence is increasingly being used by the legal profession.

item.title: Tom Daley: Olympic diving champion on winning gold, his late father, his son, and his love of knitting
item.description: In a wide-ranging interview, Tom Daley speaks exclusively to BBC Breakfast about winning Olympic gold, his family, and his love of knitting.

item.title: Nigeria's Kano state moves to ban mannequin heads on Islamic grounds
item.description: The Islamic police in Kano, Nigeria, say shop dummies with heads symbolise "idolatry" and are banned.

item.title: 'How I found out my dad was a best-selling sex writer'
item.description: Sara Faith Alterman was always close to her father. Then she learned he was concealing a secret.

item.title: Who is TikTokâs masked vigilante?
item.description: Think youâre safe being an anonymous TikTok troll or cyber bully? Meet your worst nightmare.

item.title: 'My night in Quisling's cabin'
item.description: When Ben McPherson realised he could rent Vidkun Quisling's cabin, it struck him as weird. His Norwegian wife disagreed.

item.title: 'This was a race and we lost': How US doctors really feel about Covid surge
item.description: Healthcare workers react to the growing rise of Covid patients in US hospitals despite vaccines.

item.title: Ethiopia: What do we know about aid going into Tigray?
item.description: Who's preventing desperately needed aid supplies reaching Ethiopia's Tigray region?

item.title: Sarah Rainsford on Russia: 'I've been told I can't come back - ever'
item.description: The BBC's Sarah Rainsford, devastated after being told she could not return to Russia, ever.

item.title: Shetlandâs biggest gig â the day Pulp flew in to Lerwick
item.description: At the height of their fame, the Britpop icons travelled to Lerwick to play a show for just 1,400 fans.

item.title: Will I ever be able to fly without feeling guilty again?
item.description: More efficient planes and sustainable fuels could lower air travel's impact, but not for a while.

item.title: Garth Crooks' team of the week: Alisson, Chalobah, Son, Salah, Fernandes
item.description: Which player showed why Tottenham should take the money and sell Harry Kane? Who was practically unplayable? Find out in Garth Crooks' team of the week.

item.title: Australian World Cup-winner Kefu suffers 'significant injuries' in attack at his home
item.description: Toutai Kefu and three family members suffer "significant injuries" in a suspected botched burglary.

item.title: Cavendish first rider confirmed for Tour of Britain
item.description: Mark Cavendish is the first rider confirmed for this year's Tour of Britain.

item.title: England v India: Ollie Robinson trap Ishant Sharma lbw on final day second Test
item.description: England's Ollie Robinson takes his second wicket of the morning session, trapping Ishant Sharma lbw, on the fifth day of the second Test against India.

item.title: Match of the Day 2 analysis: How an 'amazing' Spurs stopped Manchester City
item.description: Match of the Day 2's Mark Chapman, Ashley Williams and Danny Murphy look at Tottenham Hotspur's "amazing performance" as they beat Manchester City 1-0 in the Premier League.

item.title: England v India: Ollie Robinson claims wicket of Rishabh Pant
item.description: Ollie Robinson dismisses Rishabh Pant early on the final day of the second Test as England pursue victory against India.

item.title: Covid: When will teenagers get the jab and do I need a booster?
item.description: More teenagers will be able to receive the Covid vaccine, and a third jab will soon be available for the most vulnerable.

item.title: Covid rules: What's changing in Wales, Scotland, England and Northern Ireland?
item.description: Lockdown rules are changing across the UK, but some restrictions remain in place.

item.title: Covid: Do I have to self-isolate if I'm fully vaccinated?
item.description: Self-isolation rules have now been relaxed across the UK.

item.title: UK holidays: What are the rules?
item.description: Going abroad is not straightforward, so many people are opting to stay in the UK for their holidays.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: What do under-30s need to know about the vaccine?
item.description: The government has announced that 16 and 17-year-olds will receive the Covid vaccine.

item.title: Covid passport: How to prove your vaccine status with the NHS Covid Pass
item.description: Fully vaccinated adults will be able to avoid self-isolation after contact with someone with Covid.

item.title: What are the travel rules for Spain, Portugal, Malta and other holiday hotspots?
item.description: What you need to know about going to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Malta, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: Covid: What will school be like in the new term?
item.description: Pupils across the UK are preparing to return to school after the summer holidays.

item.title: Coronavirus: What do we know about the artemisia plant?
item.description: Artemisia plant extracts have anti-malarial properties, but there's no evidence they can combat Covid-19.

item.title: Covid: How do I get a lateral flow or PCR test?
item.description: Everyone in England and Scotland is being encouraged to take rapid coronavirus tests regularly.

item.title: What are the rules and guidance for face masks and coverings?
item.description: Masks are no longer compulsory in England, but remain necessary in other parts of the UK.

item.title: Wildfires: How Portuguese club Tondela drove through the flames
item.description: In Tondela, the bond between club and fans was at its strongest during the night in October 2017 when nobody slept.

item.title: Malta: The teenagers pulled from the sea and accused of terrorism
item.description: How three teenagers rescued from the Mediterranean Sea ended up in Malta accused of terrorism.

item.title: âIf only Iâd found out earlier I had pelvic congestion syndromeâ
item.description: Sophie Robehmed suffered from back and stomach pains for years before being diagnosed with PCS.
